ITEM: Not relying solely on the black syndrome, WBFO moved on to
"Nation Within a Nation", a series on the Iroquois Confederation (many
of you used that series); it is still available and timely.
ITEM: A request for foundation depth funding of a ghetto studio
to be staffed by black broadcasters was denied. WBFO is moving ahead
anyway using existing university facilities and staffing the operation
with black students who work at the station. Working with the University
Urban Extension in a new Store Front Center, WBFO hopes to begin ghetto
originations within the current year. Black students at the University
view the idea as something with meaning to them, something they can
participate in and learn from. This is an answer to those stations that
say they canTt really get involved without foundation support. Is it
really the money? Or is it a question of priorities and imagination?
Think about it.
ITEM: "Focus Intercity" hit the air two weeks ago as an open-
ended series on Saturday afternoons. It Is geared for and by the black
community. Primarily soul-folk music at the moment, the show includes
a one-hour segment called "Youth Speaks" with black kids hitting the
hard questions about themselves and about Whitey. ItTs an interesting
experiment. The Man is hearing blacks discuss him rather than the other
way around.
"Focus Intercity" will talk to anyone relevant, will take on any
issue that is a part of whatTs happening. One segment, still on the
boards, will reach for the Puerto Rican Community in Buffalo in Spanish.
Maybe WBFO is approaching some sort of millenium with white manage¬
ment hiring a black producer who includes on his series Puerto Rican
affairs in Spanish.
CONTACT: William H. Siemering, General Manager
ON TRAINING . . .
Special attention is called to the 1968 URBAN BROADCASTING WORKSHOP
to be held at the American University, Washington, D. C. during the month
of August.
Six Washington, D. C. broadcasters and the Department of Communication
at American University have developed a program to attract and train
promising urban and minority group students for work in radio-television
industry. The plan Is simple and effective:
1. Select high school juniors of promise (with aid of school
counselors, NAACP, Urban League, etc.)
2. Provide a tuition free, intensive workshop for them during
one month in the summer.
3. Select the most promising of the students for eventual decision¬
making positions in broadcasting; keep In touch with them
during their senior year of high school, motivate them, encourage
them to do their best during their last, crucial year of high
school.
